awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Multisiciplinary Research in Secure Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this proposal is to continue operation of a successful REU Site in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the University of South Carolina. The project provides students with research experiences derived from on-going research within the department in the engineering of secure software. Projects focus on one or more of the security triad of confidentiality, integrity, and availability. Participants engage in an eight-week summer research program with follow-on activities during the academic year after they return to their home institutions. These experiences: 1) encourage the computing majors to continue their studies and seek graduate degrees and research oriented careers in computer science and computer engineering; 2) encourage the pre-service teachers to continue their studies and enter the teaching profession prepared to engage their own students in research activities; 3) assist all the students in exploring employment and research opportunities available both as teachers and computing professionals; and 4) provide an enriching educational experience by exposing the students to non-classroom faculty-student interactions. The primary target participants are sophomore and junior level college students from primarily undergraduate institutions in the Southeast. Both students majoring in computing and related fields and pre-service teachers majoring in related education fields are eligible. The REU Site works closely with the South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation (SCAMP) to provide joint support for some participants. 

Intellectual Merit. The undergraduate research projects lead to the development of more effective tools and techniques for the engineering of secure, reliable and effective software. The research projects include such areas as the inclusion of security issues at early stages of software development, ensuring security on the semantic web, and maintaining availability of sensors and hand-held devices. 

Broader Impact. The program provides an opportunity for ten undergraduates to participate in research projects each year. The experience will expose them to the possibility of graduate study and encourage them to choose this step in their career paths. The emphasis on secure computing is supportive of the social need for such software. The selection process for these students promotes the inclusion of underrepresented groups through targeted publicity and outreach efforts as well as cooperation with the SCAMP program.

por.por_cntn:
The University of South Carolina REU site in Multidisciplinary Research in Secure Computing provided opportunities for 34 undergraduates to participate in ongoing research projects during its three years of operation as an REU site. An additional 19 students from the University of South Carolina received support for research participation during the following year. All participants worked with faculty and graduate student mentors. The site participants also participated in a structured series of seminars and field trips covering a wide variety of research topics and professional opportunities.

Since South Carolina is an EPSCOR state, we thought it was important to emphasize the inclusion of students from South Carolina, especially those from underrepresented groups. [EPSCOR is NSF's Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research in states that have historically had a lower level of research]. In selecting among fully qualified applicants, preference was given to students from South Carolina. Fifty percent of the REU site students were from South Carolina institutions, with the remainder from both nearby states and as far afield as Hawaii and Puerto Rico. Most of the students were from undergraduate schools or schools with limited graduate programs. A few of the participants were from Midlands Technical College, a two-year with articulation agreements with USC.  Several of the site participants from South Carolina HBCUs received some of their funding from SCAMP, the South Carolina Alliance for Minority Participation. Two of the USC students received partial funding from Access Computing, a program designed to support students with disabilities. All participants received the same overall  level of support and participated fully in all activities.

Security in computing is critical to our nation's infrastructure; building secure systems involves not just technical expertise in areas such as cryptography but also a wide variety of other approaches, including human factors issues and hardware design. Security should be an integral part of the design and implementation of any computing system. So some of the projects focused on traditional technical security issues and others included emphasis on security as part of a software project. Project were selected to build upon faculty expertise and ongoing programs consistent with the overall focus on a multidisciplinary approach to secure computing.

It is hard to measure the success of a program such as this one immediately; the results will not be evident until the participants are well advanced in their careers. Students were introduced to all aspects of research, from project design to dissemination of the results both through traditional academic publication and commercial application. Almost all projects were successfully completed, and many of the students presented their results at professional meetings. Student reaction to the program was favorable.
